abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as satisfactory
            while the project is likely to be sustainable. The overall
            Bank performance was satisfactory during the preparatory and
            implementation stages of the project. The Bank's team
            maintained a reasonable level of continuity of team
            membership, and the Government appreciated the systematic
            and well-structured approach for the project formulation,
            design implementation, monitoring, supervision, and
            evaluation. The Borrower's overall performance was
            rated as satisfactory. Lessons learned are as follows: 1)
            Strong central leadership and close supportive supervision
            at the provincial level are critical to the success of the
            project from a policy, technical, and resource mobilization
            and allocation perspective. This could have been enhanced if
            senior managers at central and provincial levels would have
            had orientation sessions given the introduction of novel
            approaches and/or methodologies. In the context of this
            project this would have involved the clinical and
            epidemiological aspects of the project and management
            sciences applications in health systems and development. 2)
            Identify and distinguish the interdependence of the project
            components in terms of their timing of the implementation,
            technical content, and the communications and collaboration
            required for those involved in the planning, development,
            and implementation of the different components. 3)
            Procurement procedures should include an appropriately
            multi-disciplinary and independent expert group, including
            bioengineers to set the technical specifications,
            contractual conditions, and vetting procedures for health
            facility equipment appropriate to the level of care, skills
            required, and anticipated caseload of the facility. 4) With
            regard to training health workers, a portion of the training
            infrastructure needs to be maintained, and additional
            distance learning methods adapted to meeting on-going
            training of new staff and updating of skills. 5) In
            planning, implementing, and facilitating continuity in the
            development of the newer, and somewhat unfamiliar components
            of a project, a more strategic integrative approach should
            be used. Project management could be further improved by
            conducting management training in small, participatory
            groups, multi-disciplinary in character and involve staff
            working at the same and supervisory levels. There is also a
            need for incorporating principles of translation and
            retranslation when drawing from technical materials
            originally prepared in other languages. 6) Financial
            arrangements should be simplified and the burden imposed on
            the most needy communities and families lessened in order to
            overcome the social and economic obstacles to accessing
            health care.
